html.p: The Databricks Add-on for Splunk allows Splunk teams to take advantage of the effective cost model of Databricks along with the power of AI without asking users to leave the comforts of their Splunk interface.

Users can run ad-hoc queries against Databricks from within a Splunk dashboard or search bar with the add-on. Those who have notebooks or jobs in Databricks can launch them through a Splunk dashboard or in response to a Splunk search. The Databricks integration is also bi-directional, letting customers summarize noisy data or run detections in Databricks that show up in Splunk Enterprise Security. Customers can even run Splunk searches from within a Databricks notebook so that they don’t need to duplicate all of their data to get the job done.

The Splunk and Databricks integration allows customers to reduce their cost, expand the data sources they analyze, and provide the results of a more robust analytics engine, all without changing the tools used all day by their staff.

html.p: There are three main integration points, as shown in the slide above:

ol.li: This app enables running queries from Splunk against Databricks by configuring a personal access token for a service account within Databricks. Additionally, you can launch ephemeral notebook runs or jobs. See the app docs for more detail.

You can also configure the Splunk DB Connect app to run searches against Databricks via JDBC. The API used for this add-on is limited to 1000 results when running a simple query, but JDBC can pull back almost infinite amount of data. Additionally, as DB Connect supports multiple profiles, you can configure multiple connections with different levels of access. See our integration docs for configuration instructions.

You can also send data from Databricks to Splunk via Splunk's HTTP Event Collector. This could be small sets of data, such as security alerts detected via AI on Databricks, or large sets of data such as aggregated or filtered high volume datasets. You can also use the Splunk REST API to run queries against data stored in Splunk from Databricks.

html.p: To configure the Databricks Add-on, Navigate to the configuration page from the navigation bar above and Click on "Add" button and then follow these steps:

ol.li: Enter the databricks instance url in the "Databricks Instance" field without a schema (http or https)
Select the mode through which databricksquery command needs to be executed from "'databricksquery' to run on" dropdown.
Select the authentication type from the dropdown.
Based on the authentication type, enter the required credentials. (Refer the image above)

If you select the "Personal Access Token" Authentication Type then, enter the personal access token for the same instance in the "Databricks Access Token" field. Else provide the "Client Id", "Tenant Id" and "Client Secret".
*optional* Enter the cluster you want to associate to every query and notebook execution. It can be overridden later.
Click "Add" button to save the configuration.

html.p: **Note: User with 'admin' role can do the Configuration of the Account and Proxy, whereas users without 'admin' role can't do the Configuration or view it.

html.p: To launch a notebook through Adaptive Response in Splunk Enterprise Security Suite, follow these steps:

ol.li: Navigate to the Incident Review dashboard in your Splunk Enterprise Security App.
Find the "Incident Review Events" panel in the dashboard and look for notable threats in the table.
Click on the chaperone icon ">" on any one of the events which will expand the event for actions.
Find the "Actions" column on the top-right corner of the panel and click on the "down" arrow to expand and then select "Run Adaptive Response Actions"
This will open a dialog box in which, there will be a button to "Add a new Response Action". Click it and then select "Launch Notebook" from the dropdown.
Provide the absolute path of the notebook and provide notebook parameters (if required) and the cluster to which the notebook is associated and select account name and then hit "Run".
Close the dialog box and keep refreshing the "Adaptive Responses" field as shown in the video until the link to the notebook results appears with Status as "Success".
Then click on the "Launch Notebook" drilldown/link as shown which will redirect you to the "Launch Notebook" page of the Databricks Add-on
Finally, click "click here" to get redirected to the URL of the results of the notebook execution on your databricks instance.

panel.title: Launching a Notebook through Splunk search

html.p: To launch a notebook via Splunk search, follow these steps:

ol.li: Navigate to Splunk Seach app either from the "Apps" dropdown or the Navigation bar.
Enter the custom command "databricksrun" as shown in the image with the required parameters and hit enter.

html.p:
The app provides three custom commands. Users can open the Splunk search bar and can execute the commands. Below are the command details.
databricksquery: used to query data present in the Databricks table from Splunk. Refer docs for the command parameter details.
Syntax 1: | databricksquery warehouse_id="<warehouse_id>" limit=<query_result_limit> query="<SQL_query>" command_timeout=<timeout_in_seconds> account_name="<account_name>"
Syntax 2: | databricksquery cluster="<cluster_name>" query="<SQL_query>" command_timeout=<timeout_in_seconds> account_name="<account_name>"
databricksrun: used to submit a one-time run for a notebook without creating a job. Refer docs for the command parameter details.
Syntax: | databricksrun notebook_path="<path_to_notebook>" run_name="<run_name>" cluster="<cluster_name>" revision_timestamp=<revision_timestamp> notebook_params="<params_for_job_execution>" account_name="<account_name>"
databricksjob: used to run an already created job now from Splunk. Refer docs for the command parameter details.
Syntax: | databricksjob job_id=<job_id> notebook_params="<params_for_job_execution>" account_name="<account_name>"
